Description: Corner fragment of terracotta relief plaque. The top right-hand corner of a relief plaque, with a double moulding along the top and a single one down the side. What remains shows foodstuffs, including two root vegetables, which dangle from the lower moulding flanking a circular loaf that is stamped with a cross with single raised points in the angles. Also to be seen is an uncertain long, narrow spike-shaped object, possibly another root vegetable (but it is upside down), and a wine-amphora. Although of exaggerated form, the body-shape of the amphora and its tall narrow neck probably indicate a vessel of Hellenistic (or late Classical) date. The back is flat. One-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown clay with a buff surface and a thick grey core, containing white grits.
Curator's comments: Although not certainly of Egyptian manufacture, the fabric makes this highly likely and this was found with other unregistered Egyptian objects (mostly from Naukratis). Likely from a figure plaque that would also depict a nude female or erotic scene that commonly date to the Late Period and Ptolemaic period, which are known to depict amphorae in the background (See Thomas Type P-E.1 and P-F.3.3; GR 1973,0501.54). If indeed from a symplegma plaque (erotic scene), there are parallels of such plaques from the Fayum (Weber 1914, no. 352), Memphis (Petrie Museum UC 48436; Thomas & Nicholson 2013, 232-4, P-393) and unprovenanced (UC38349; particulaly UC35953 dated, incorrectly?, 29th Dynasty) probably all Late Period to 4th century BC in date. Late Period (Fisher 1994, no.513) and 4th to 3rd century BC parallels (Bayer Niemeier 1988, no.458). Parallels with later (erronous) dates include a '2nd to 1st century BC' example said to be from Antinoe(?) (Besques 1992, D/E 4516, provenanceis unlikely to be correct) and a late 1st to 2nd century AD (Fjeldhagen 1995, no. 105). Besques, S. 1992, Catalogue raisonné des figurines et reliefs en terre-cuite grecs, étrusques et romains IV/2. Époques hellénistique et romaine. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen, Wasmuth. Fjeldhagen, M.1995. Catalogue. Graeco-Roman terracottas from Egypt. Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek. Copenhagen. Thomas, R. I. & Nicholson, P.
